information_requirement: Is an adversary attempting to intercept credentials or access tokens by hijacking URI schemes on mobile devices? (PIR)

evidence.description: A newly installed or low-reputation application registers a URI scheme that is identical to a URI scheme registered by a known, legitimate application, particularly one used for authentication (e.g., OAuth).
data_sources: Mobile Device Management (MDM) application inventory logs
evidence.nai: Corporate-managed mobile endpoints (iOS and Android devices)
evidence.action: Continuously collect an inventory of all installed applications and their registered URI schemes from all managed mobile devices via MDM/MTD. Establish and maintain an allow-list of known, legitimate applications and their expected URI schemes (e.g., 'mybank://', 'corp-sso://'). For each device, programmatically identify any instances where two or more applications register the same URI scheme, indicating a collision. For each collision, apply a risk score. Increase the score if one app is a known, high-value target (e.g., banking, SSO) and the other has a low reputation, is from an untrusted developer, or was recently installed. Use descriptive statistics to identify apps that register an anomalous number of URI schemes compared to a fleet-wide baseline. High-risk collisions should trigger an alert for analyst investigation.
